paragraphs.text: Okay, so maybe hearing criticism is a little difficult for all of us. But, in order to become more successful, it’s necessary. And, to become radically successful, you may even need to start asking for feedback.
paragraphs.name: bca2

paragraphs.text: But, as the popular saying goes: “Don’t make a permanent decision from your temporary emotion.”
paragraphs.name: bcdc

paragraphs.text: Studies have found that shifting from a fixed mindset to a growth mindset results in radical success. If you aren’t familiar with these terms: A growth mindset is one that believes intelligence and skill can be developed, while a fixed mindset is one that believes intelligence and skill are static.
paragraphs.name: e3c1

paragraphs.text: Great compilation Elle. Thanks.
paragraphs.name: 58ed

paragraphs.text: All but the first: Excellent!
paragraphs.name: 61e6

paragraphs.text: In particular, the Fixed Mindset. Toxic on both ends, at least to math students. (I’m studying to be a high school math teacher. Student teaching this coming fall.) paragraphs.text: Words of wisdom. I had problem with hearing criticism once. But I’ve learned that feedback is the most powerful tool.
Thanks for sharing this piece.
paragraphs.name: 00be

4b842a966fea.title: Great article — the feedback one is critical.

paragraphs.text: Great article — the feedback one is critical. When I made the career change to becoming a designer, this was a struggle for me to begin with, as every little finite detail of your work is critiqued––constantly and mercilessly! Over time I’ve learned to relish feedback as an opportunity to improve my work, or perhaps educate the other stakeholders in the project as to the methods behind my madness :D

paragraphs.text: Would you consider acknowledging those who helped you along in your career, and those upon whose shoulders you stand, as a way to keep perspective and stay humble? It not only helps with your own sanity, but it helps people you need, want to help you.
